revision.text:
{{Infobox noble|type | name = Peter Dóczy
Petar Doci | title = {{Plainlist | * [[Voivode|Vaivoda]]{{cite book|author1=Matthias I (King of Hungary)|author2=Vilmos Fraknói|author3=Magyar Tudományos Akadémia|title=Mátyás király levelei: Külügyi osztály|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZfIYAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=12 February 2013|year=1893|publisher=Magyar tudományos akadémia|page=383}} * [[Castellan|Captain]] of [[Belgrade fortress|Belgrade]] * [[Ban (title)|Ban]] of [[Jajce Fortress|Jajce]] }} | image = | caption = | alt = | CoA = | more = no | reign = | reign-type = | predecessor = | successor = | suc-type = | succession = | spouse = | spouse-type = | issue = | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | full name = | styles = | titles = | noble family = | house-type = | father = | mother = | birth_date = | birth_place = | christening_date = | christening_place = | death_date = | death_place = | burial_date = | burial_place = | religion = | occupation = }} '''Peter Dóczy{{cite book|author1=Franz Babinger|author2=Ralph Manheim (translator)|title=Mehmed the Conqueror and His Time|url=https://books.google.hu/books?id=PPxC6rO7vvsC&pg=PA375&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Doczy%22&f=false|accessdate=26 July 2013|year=1978|publisher=Princeton University Press}} de Nagylucse''' ({{lang-hu|nagylucsei Dóczy Péter}}; {{lang-sr|Petar Doci}}) was a 15th-century Hungarian nobleman. In 1462 he was a captain of the [[Belgrade]] fortress. Around 1479 he was a commander of the [[Hungary|Hungarian]] fleet on Danube in [[Varadin]]. In 1480 he was a [[Ban (title)|ban]] of [[Jajce Fortress|Jajce]] ({{lang-hu|Jajca}}) in [[Bosnia (region)|Bosnia]].{{cite book|author1=Milman Parry|author2=Albert B. Lord|title=Serbocroation heroic songs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X3UWAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|year=1979|publisher=Harvard University Press}}{{cite book|author=Ivan Kukuljević Sakcinski|title=Izabrana djela|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IMkXAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|year=1997|publisher=Matica hrvatska}} == Name == The alternative names of Peter Dóczy include ''Petrus de Docz'', ''Petrus Doczy'',{{cite book|author1=Dragoslav Srejović|author2=Slavko Gavrilović|author3=Sima M. Ćirković|title=Istorija srpskog naroda: knj. Doba borbi za očuvanje i obnovu države (1371-1537)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ugJAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|publisher=Srpska književna zadruga|page=578}}{{cite book|author=Јованка Калић-Мијушковић|title=Београд у средњем веку|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HFsBAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|year=1967|publisher=Српска књижевна задруга|page=197}} ''Petar Dojčin'', ''Petar Dovac'', ''Peter Doći''{{cite book|author1=Đura Daničić|author2=Jugoslavenska akademija znanosti i umjetnosti|title=Rječnik hrvatskoga ili srpskoga jezika|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7O4GAAAAQAAJ|accessdate=15 February 2013|year=1882|publisher=U knížarnici L. Hartmana na prodaju|page=169}} and ''Petar Varadinac''.{{cite book|title=Zbornik Matice srpske za književnost i jezik|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R7NiAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=16 February 2013|year=1970|publisher=Matica srpska|page=187}} == Career == In 1462 Dóczy was a captain of the Belgrade fortress.{{cite book|author=Јованка Калић-Мијушковић|title=Београд у средњем веку|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HFsBAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|year=1967|publisher=Српска књижевна задруга}} In period between 1476 and 1479 he was a commander of the Hungarian fleet of hundred ships on Danube and [[Sava River|Sava]].{{cite book|title=Godis̆njak grada Beograda|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nVTjAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=15 February 2013|year=1979|publisher=Beogradske novine|page=19}} A part of his fleet participated in Hungarian capture of [[Šabac]] ({{lang-hu|Szabács}}) in 1476. In 1480 he was a ban of Jajce.{{cite book|title=Zbornik Matice srpske: Serija društvenih nauka|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X5YaAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|year=1951|publisher=Naučno odeljenje Matice srpske}} At the end of 1480, together with [[Vuk Grgurević Branković]] and Hungarian ban of Slavonia [[Ladislaus Egervári]], Dóczy attacked and plundered the [[Sanjak of Bosnia]] whose [[sanjakbey]] was [[Koca Davud Pasha]].{{cite book|author1=Esma Smailbegović|author2=RO Institut za jezik i književnost (Sarajevo, Bosnia and Hercegovina)|title=Narodna predanja o Sarajevu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z_8LAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|year=1986|publisher=institut za jezik i književnost, OOUR Institut za književnost|page=113}} They managed to reach [[Vrhbosna]]{{cite book|title=Летопис Матице српске|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kf3QAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=15 February 2013|year=1909|publisher=У Српској народној задружној штампарији|page=27}} and plundered it for three days.{{cite book|title=Istorijski Glasnik|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9RfjAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=15 February 2013|year=1952|page=7}} Dóczy traveled to [[Istanbul]] to meet [[Ottomans|Ottoman]] sultan [[Mehmed the Conqueror|Mehmed]] two times as envoy of the Hungarian king [[Matthias Corvinus]].{{cite book|author1=Dragoslav Srejović|author2=Slavko Gavrilović|author3=Sima M. Ćirković|title=Istorija srpskog naroda: knj. Doba borbi za očuvanje i obnovu države (1371-1537)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ugJAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|publisher=Srpska književna zadruga|page=385}} On 9 September 1482 Dóczy, Grgurević and Pavle Kanjiži defeated Ottoman forces of 10,000 spearmen near [[Bečej|Óbecse]] (today: ''Bečej, Serbia'').{{cite book|author1=Vladimir Ćorović|author2=Nenad Ljubinković|author3=Irena Arsić|title=Istorija srpskog naroda|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kRUWAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|year=1997|publisher=Glas srpski}} Ottomans had intention to reach and plunder the region of [[Timișoara|Temesvár]] (today: ''Timișoara, Romania'').{{cite book|title=Proceedings in history|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1BMWAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=15 February 2013|year=1971|publisher=Odeljenje za društvene nauke, Matica srpska|page=21}} == In Serbian epic poetry == In [[Serbian epic poetry]] Dóczy became Petar Dojčin, ban of Varadin.{{cite book|author=Milan Prelog|title=Povijest Bosne u doba osmanlijske vlade ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0UwCAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=4 February 2013|date=1924*|publisher=Naklada J. Studnička i druga}} The most famous epic song about Petar Dojčin is ''"Dojčin Petar and King Matthias"'' ({{lang-sr|Дојчин Петар и Краљ Матијаш}}) also known as "Petar Dojčin drinks wine" ({{lang-sr|Вино пије Дојчин Петар}}), which is published for the first time in period between 1716 and 1733 in [[Erlangen Manuscript]].{{cite book|title=Zbornik Matice srpske za književnost i jezik|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R7NiAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=16 February 2013|year=1970|publisher=Matica srpska|page=187}}{{cite book|author=Cetinje (Montenegro) Etnografski muzeji|title=Glasnik: Bulletin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aehCLa4m5_sC|accessdate=16 February 2013|year=1961|page=145}} Petar Dojčin and [[Bolani Dojčin]], another hero of Serbian epic poetry, are unrelated. == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Doczy, Peter}} [[Category:15th-century births]] [[Category:Characters in Serbian epic poetry]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:15th-century Hungarian nobility]] [[Category:Hungarian generals]] [[Category:15th century in Serbia]] [[Category:15th century in Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
